content: Results and DiscussionRational Design of Dissymmetric Cages Composed ofConformational EnantiomersFrom achiral precursors triamino-functionalized TABPBand trialdehyde-containing TP, wesynthesized aseries ofDC molecules with different alkyloxy groups oneachterphenyl pillar (Figure 1b), except forDC-1 without lateralmoiety.[30]EachDCmolecule iscomposed ofabenzene roof(inblue), atris(N-salicylideneamine) bottom (inyellow),and three terphenyl pillars. Inorder torelease the strainduring theformation ofacage, thethree pillars twist eitherclockwise ((P)-DC) oranti-clockwise ((M)-DC). Itthereforeyields amixture oftwo conformational enantiomers (calledatropo-enantiomers) with apropeller-like shape. The crys-tallographic analysis reveals that each enantiomer hasaC3-axis ofrotation asthe only element ofsymmetry, butwithout inversion center ormirror plane. Their detailedsynthetic procedures,1Hand13CNMR and MALDI-TOFanalyses aregiven intheSupporting Information. The singlecrystals ofDC-1 were grown byslow evaporation ofitsethyl[*] Y.Zuo,+X. Liu,+E. Fu,+S. ZhangSchool of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Shanghai Jiao TongUniversity800 Dongchuan Road, Shanghai 200240 (China)E-mail: sdzhang@sjtu.edu.cn[1]These authors contributed equally to this work.

[31] Deposition Numbers 1922163 (forDC-1), 2214400 (forDC-2),2214402 (for(M)-DC-3), 2214404 (for(M)-DC-4), 2214464 (for(P)-DC-4), and 2214405 (forDC-5) contain thesupplementarycrystallographic data forthis paper. These data areprovidedfree ofcharge bythejoint Cambridge Crystallographic DataCentre and Fachinformationszentrum Karlsruhe Access Struc-tures service.

1,3,5-Tris(3-bromophenyl)benzene (1): 3'-bromoacetophenone (19.90 g, 100 mmol) was dissolved in 40 mL of EtOH and the mixture was kept at 0 oC. SOCl2 (27 mL, 372 mmol) was added dropwise slowly to mixture at 0 oC and then the reaction was refluxed for 3 h. After cooling to room temperature, the reaction was quenched slowly by saturated NaHCO3 and then EtOH was added to form large amount of white solid which was collected by filtration. The solid was recrystallized with DCM/EtOH. The white crystal (10.55 g, 39.0% yield) was collected by filtration and washed with EtOH (3 ¡ä 100 mL). 1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3, 298 K) ¦Ä 7.82 (s, 3H), 7.71 (s, 3H), 7.61 (d, J = 8.0 Hz, 3H), 7.54 (d, J = 8.0 Hz, 3H), 7.36 (t, J = 16.0, 8.0 Hz, 3H). 13C NMR (101 MHz, CDCl3, 298 K) ¦Ä 142.88, 141.39, 130.92, 130.60, 130.50, 126.13, 125.69, 123.21.

2-(3-{3,5-Bis[3-(tetramethyl-1,3,2-dioxaborolan-2-yl)phenyl]phenyl}phenyl)-4,4,5,5-tetramethyl-1,3,2-dioxaborolane (2): A Schlenk flask charged with compound 1 (6.81 g, 12.5 mmol), bis(pinacolato)diboron (11.43 g, 45.0 mmol), PdCl2(dppf) (0.92 g, 1.25 mmol), and potassium acetate (18.40 g, 187.5 mmol) was S6  purged with N2 for three times, and then anhydrous 1,4-dioxane (200 mL) was added under nitrogen atmosphere. The reaction mixture was stirred at 90 oC for 12 h. Organic solvent was removed under reduced pressure and the residue was extracted with DCM (3 ¡ä 100 mL) and washed with brine (100 mL), dried over MgSO4. The crude product was purified by column chromatography on silica gel with EtOAc/PE = 1/8 (v/v) to yield a white solid (7.04 g, 82.3% yield). 1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3, 298 K) ¦Ä 8.12 (s, 3H), 7.83 (d, J = 8.0 Hz, 3H), 7.80 (s, 3H), 7.80 (d, J = 8.0 Hz, 3H), 7.49 (t, J = 16.0, 8.0 Hz, 3H), 1.37 (s, 36H). 13C NMR (101 MHz, CDCl3, 298 K) ¦Ä 142.37, 140.78, 134.00, 133.93, 130.49, 128.34, 125.54, 84.05, 25.04.  3-(3-Aminophenyl)-5-bromophenol (3): Into a 500 mL Schlenk flask were charged 3,5-dibromophenol (10.83 g, 43.0 mmol), 3-aminobenzeneboronic acid (3.57 g, 26.0 mmol), Pd(PPh3)4 (1.49 g, 1.29 mmol), and potassium carbonate (23.77 g, 172.0 mmol). The flask was degassed with N2 for three times, in which 220 mL of 1,4-dioxane and 55 mL of water were added then. The reaction mixture was stirred at 90 oC for 12 h. Organic solvent was removed under reduced pressure and the residue was extracted with EtOAc (3 ¡ä 100 mL) and washed with brine (100 mL). The organic phase was collected together and dried over MgSO4, concentrated under reduced pressure. The crude residue was purified by column chromatography on silica gel with EtOAc/PE = 1/2 (v/v) to yield a yellow solid (4.40 g, 64.0% yield). 1H NMR (400 MHz, acetone-d6, 298 K) ¦Ä 8.83 (s, 1H), 7.20 (t, J = 3.2, 1.6 Hz, 1H), 7.13 (t, J = 16.0, 8.0 Hz, 1H), 7.03 (t, J = 3.6, 1.8 Hz, 1H), 6.99 (t, J = 4.0, 2.0 Hz, 1H), 6.91 (t, J = 4.0, 2.0 Hz, 1H), 4.75 (s, 2H). 13C NMR (101 MHz, acetone-d6, 298 K) ¦Ä 159.51, 149.85, 145.98, 141.12, 130.37, 123.31, 121.77, 117.79, 116.12, 114.95, 113.77, 113.56.  S7  3-(3-Bromo-5-methoxyphenyl)aniline (4): Into a 250 mL Schlenk flask were charged 1,3-dibromo-5-methoxybezene (2.66 g, 10.0 mmol), 3-aminobenzeneboronic acid (1.37 g, 10.0 mmol), Pd(PPh3)4 (0.35 g, 0.30 mmol), and potassium carbonate (4.14 g, 30.0 mmol). The flask was degassed with N2 for three times, in which 100 mL of 1,4-dioxane and 25 mL of water were added then. The reaction mixture was stirred at 90 oC for 12 h. Organic solvent was removed under reduced pressure and the residue was extracted with DCM (3 ¡ä 80 mL) and washed with brine (80 mL). The organic phase was collected together and dried over MgSO4, concentrated under reduced pressure. The crude residue was purified by column chromatography on silica gel with DCM/PE = 1/1 (v/v) to yield a yellow solid (1.69 g, 60.8% yield). 1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3, 298 K) ¦Ä 7.29 (t, J = 2.4, 1.2 Hz, 1H), 7.21 (t, J = 8.0, 4.0 Hz, 1H), 7.01 (t, J = 3.2, 1.6 Hz, 2H), 6.93 (d, J = 8.0 Hz, 1H), 6.85 (t, J = 4.0, 2.0 Hz, 1H), 6.69 (dd, J = 7.6, 1.2 Hz, 1H), 3.84 (s, 3H), 3.77 (br, 2H). 13C NMR (101 MHz, CDCl3, 298 K) ¦Ä 160.55, 146.90, 144.44, 140.99, 129.88, 123.06, 122.80, 117.61, 115.82, 114.83, 113.82, 112.16, 55.67.  3-(3-Bromo-5-ethoxyphenyl)aniline (5): A Schlenk flask charged with compound 3 (1.05 g, 4.0 mmol) and potassium carbonate (0.83 g, 6.0 mmol) was purged with N2 for three times and then bromoethane (1.31 g, 6.0 mmol) and 50 mL of acetonitrile was added under N2 atmosphere. The reaction mixture was refluxed for 36 h. Organic solvent was removed under reduced pressure and the residue was extracted with DCM (3 ¡ä 60 mL) and washed with brine (60 mL). The organic phase was collected together and dried over MgSO4, concentrated under reduced pressure. The crude product was purified by column chromatography on silica gel with EtOAc/PE = 1/3 (v/v) to yield a yellow oil (0.61 g, 51.8% yield). 1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3, 298 K) ¦Ä 7.28 (t, J = 3.2, 1.6 Hz, 1H), 7.21 (t, J = 16.0, 8.0 Hz, 1H), 7.01 (s, 1H), 7.00 (s, 1H), 6.93 (d, J = 7.6 Hz, 1H), 6.85 (t, J = 4.0, 2.0 Hz, 1H), 6.69 (dd, J = 8.0, 1.6 Hz, S8  1H), 4.06 (q, J = 6.8 Hz, 2H), 3.74 (br, 2H), 1.43 (t, J = 13.6, 6.8 Hz, 3H). 13C NMR (101 MHz, CDCl3, 298 K) ¦Ä 159.93, 146.89, 144.39, 141.07, 129.88, 123.05, 122.65, 117.63, 116.36, 114.79, 113.83, 112.68, 63.98, 14.89.  3-[3-Bromo-5-(propan-2-yloxy)phenyl]aniline (6): A Schlenk flask charged with compound 3 (4.49 g, 17.0 mmol) and potassium carbonate (4.70 g, 34.0 mmol) was purged with N2 for three times and then 2-bromopropane (3.14 g, 25.5 mmol) and 100 mL of acetonitrile was added under N2 atmosphere. The reaction mixture was refluxed for 36 h. Organic solvent was removed under reduced pressure and the residue was extracted with DCM (3 ¡ä 100 mL) and washed with brine (100 mL). The organic phase was collected together and dried over MgSO4, concentrated under reduced pressure. The crude product was purified by column chromatography on silica gel with EtOAc/PE = 1/3 (v/v) to yield a yellow oil (3.99 g, 76.9% yield). 1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3, 298 K) ¦Ä 7.25 (s, 1H), 7.21 (t, J = 16.0, 8.0 Hz, 1H), 6.99 (t, J = 2.8, 1.4 Hz, 2H), 6.92 (d, J = 7.6 Hz, 1H), 6.84 (t, J = 4.0, 2.0 Hz, 1H), 4.61¨C4.53 (m, 1H), 3.74 (s, 2H), 1.35 (d, J = 6.0 Hz, 6H). 13C NMR (101 MHz, CDCl3, 298 K) ¦Ä 158.95, 146.90, 144.47, 141.16, 129.89, 123.07, 122.61, 117.71, 117.68, 114.79, 113.95, 113.87, 70.59, 22.14.  3-(3-Bromo-5-butoxyphenyl)aniline (7): A Schlenk flask charged with compound 3 (0.79 g, 3.0 mmol) and potassium carbonate (0.83 g, 6.0 mmol) was purged with N2 for three times and then 1-bromobutane (0.62 g, 4.5 mmol) and 50 mL of acetonitrile was added under N2 atmosphere. The reaction mixture was refluxed for 36 S9  h. Organic solvent was removed under reduced pressure and the residue was extracted with DCM (3 ¡ä 60 mL) and washed with brine (60 mL). The organic phase was collected together and dried over MgSO4, concentrated under reduced pressure. The crude product was purified by column chromatography on silica gel with DCM/PE = 1/1 (v/v) to yield a yellow oil (0.80 g, 83.2% yield). 1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3, 298 K) ¦Ä 7.27 (s, 1H), 7.21 (t, J = 16.0, 8.0 Hz, 1H), 7.01 (s, 1H), 7.00 (s, 1H), 6.94 (d, J = 7.6 Hz, 1H), 6.86 (s, 1H), 6.69 (dd, J = 7.6, 1.6 Hz, 1H), 3.99 (t, J = 12.8, 6.4 Hz, 2H), 3.80 (br, 2H), 1.83¨C1.72 (m, 2H), 1.56¨C1.44 (m, 2H), 0.99 (t, J = 14.4, 7.2 Hz, 3H). 13C NMR (101 MHz, CDCl3, 298 K) ¦Ä 160.17, 146.80, 144.38, 141.13, 129.89, 123.05, 122.60, 117.72, 116.41, 114.84, 113.90, 112.70, 68.21, 31.35, 19.35, 13.97.

3-(3-{3-[3,5-Bis({3-[3-(3-aminophenyl)-5-methoxyphenyl]phenyl})phenyl]-phenyl}-5-ethoxyphenyl)aniline (8): Into a 100 mL Schlenk flask were charged compound 2 (0.82 g, 1.2 mmol), compound 4 (1.10 g, 4.0 mmol), Pd(PPh3)4 (0.14 g, 0.12 mmol), and potassium carbonate (2.48 g, 18.0 mmol). The flask was degassed with N2 for three times, in which 24 mL of 1,4-dioxane and 6 mL of water were added then. The reaction mixture was stirred at 90 oC for 24 h. Organic solvent was removed under reduced pressure and the residue was extracted with DCM (3 ¡ä 50 mL) and washed with brine (50 mL). The organic phase was collected together and dried over MgSO4, concentrated under reduced pressure. The crude residue was purified by column chromatography on silica gel with EtOAc/PE = 2/3 (v/v) to yield a light yellow solid (0.81 g, 75.2% yield). 1H NMR (400 MHz, DMSO-d6, 298 K) ¦Ä 8.17 (s, 3H), 8.10 (s, 3H), 7.91 (d, J = 7.6 Hz, 3H), 7.76 (d, J = 7.6 Hz, 3H), 7.62 (t, J = 15.2, 7.6 Hz, 3H), 7.47 (s, 3H), 7.30 (s, 3H), 7.16¨C7.04 (m, 6H), 6.94 (s, 3H), 6.89 (d, J = 7.6 Hz, 3H), S10  6.59 (dd, J = 8.0, 1.6 Hz, 3H), 5.17 (s, 6H), 3.88 (s, 9H). 13C NMR (101 MHz, CDCl3, 298 K) ¦Ä 160.36, 146.86, 143.56, 142.97, 142.64, 142.38, 142.07, 141.79, 129.83, 129.48, 126.80, 126.58, 125.74, 119.11, 117.89, 114.51, 114.11, 112.05, 111.99, 55.62.

S13  2,4,6-Trihydroxybenzene-1,3,5-tricarbaldehyde (TP): Phloroglucinol (2.00 g, 15.9 mmol) and formamidine acetate (8.25 g, 79.4 mmol) were combined in 200 mL of THF in a round-bottom flask. At 45 oC acetic anhydride (14.7 mL, 159.0 mmol) was added, and the reaction allowed to proceed for 24 h. The reaction was worked up by evaporating THF solvent and leftover acetic anhydride under reduced pressure at 50 oC, followed by stirring in water (200 mL) at 45 oC for 2 h. Aqueous LiOH (3 mol/L, 400 mL, 1200 mmol) was added slowly, then stirring continued for 20 h. Aqueous hydrochloric acid was added to re-acidify the solution to pH = 3¨C4, causing a light red powder to precipitate. The precipitate was extracted with CHCl3 (3 ¡ä 100 mL) and dried over MgSO4, decolored by active carbon. The organic phase was collected by filtration and concentrated to yield a light grey powder (0.99 g, 30.0% yield). 1H NMR (400 MHz, DMSO-d6, 298 K) ¦Ä 9.98 (s, 3H), 5.01 (br, 3H). 13C NMR (101 MHz, DMSO-d6, 298 K) ¦Ä 191.47, 173.38, 103.21.

(a) CD spectra of 206 random single crystals of DC-4 dissolved in chloroform. The number ratio to single crystal of (P)-DC-4 and (M)-DC-4 is 48:52. Due to different size of each crystal, the sum of positive and negative ellipticity at 395 nm was calculated respectively. The sum of positive ellipticity value at 395 nm is 176.24, and that of negative one is ?178.16, therefore with a ellipticity ratio of 49.7:50.3. It indicates equal probability of (P)- and (M)-DC-4 conglomerates. (b) CD spectra of 16 random single crystals of DC-3 dissolved in chloroform. The sum of positive ellipticity value at 395 nm is 26.66, and that of negative one is ?26.15, also indicating equal probability of (P)- and (M)-DC-3 conglomerates. (c) Experimental and simulated CD spectra of (P)-DC-4. (d) Experimental and simulated UV-vis spectra of DC-4.

Materials Reagents and solvents were purchased from commercial suppliers and used without further purification, unless other indicated. 1,4-Dioxane and tetrahydrofuran (THF) was dried over sodium and distilled under nitrogen before use. Bis(pinacolato)diboron, 3'-bromoacetophenone, 3-aminobenzeneboronic acid, 1,3-dibromo-5-methoxybezene, bromoethane, 2-bromopropane, 1-bromobutane, phloroglucinol, formamidine acetate, trifluoroacetic acid (TFA), lithium diisopropylamide (LDA, 2 mol/L in THF/heptane) and catalyst [1,1'-bis(diphenylphosphino)ferrocene] dichloropalladium(II) [PdCl2(dppf)] were purchased from Adamas-beta, China. 3,5-Dibromophenol and catalyst tetrakis(triphenylphosphine)palladium [Pd(PPh3)4] were purchased from Bidepharm, China. Thionylchloride (SOCl2) and inorganic salts including potassium carbonate, potassium acetate, sodium bicarbonate and magnesium sulfate were purchased from Greagent, China. Flash column chromatography was performed on silica gel (200¨C300 mesh) and the compounds were visualized under 254 nm on thin-layer chromatography (TLC) plates.  2. Techniques 2.1 Nuclear Magnetic Resonance (NMR) 1H NMR and 13C NMR spectra were recorded at 400 MHz and 101 MHz on a Bruker A V ANCE III HD 400 NMR spectrometer. NMR spectra were measured at 298 K in CDCl3, acetone-d6 or DMSO-d6. Their proton residuals are used as internal reference for 1H NMR, respectively. Proton and carbon chemical shifts (¦Ä) are reported in ppm and coupling constants (J) in Hertz (Hz). The multiplicity in the 1H NMR spectra are described as s (singlet); d (doublet); dd (doublet of doublets); t (triplet); q (quartet); m (multiplet); br (broad). 2.2 Matrix-Assisted Laser Desorption/Ionization Time of Flight (MALDI-TOF) Mass Spectrometry MALDI-TOF mass spectrometry was performed on a Bruker Autoflex speed TOF/TOF mass spectrometer and operated in reflective mode. Internal calibration was S4  performed using peptide (700-3500 Dalton) as standards. The analytical samples were obtained by mixing the CHCl3 solution of the sample (5 mg/mL) and CH2Cl2 solution of the matrix (trans-2-[3-(4-tert-butylphenyl)-2-methyl-2-propene]-malononitrile (DCTB, 10 mg/mL) in a 1/5 (v/v) ratio. The prepared mixture solution of the sample (1 ¦ÌL) was loaded on the MALDI-TOF plate and allowed to dry at 25 oC before the plate was inserted into the vacuum chamber of the MALDI-TOF instrument. 2.3 Single Crystal X-Ray Diffractometry (SC-XRD) The single crystal data of cages were collected on Bruker D8 VENTURE. The structures were solved by direct methods using the OLEX-2 software. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined using anisotropic thermal parameters.  2.4 Circular Dichroism (CD) Circular dichroism (CD) was performed with a JASCO J-1500 spectrometer. CD spectra of the solution of the cages were recorded in 1 mm quartz cuvettes at 25 oC after single crystals were picked up randomly and dissolved in 250 ¦ÌL of chloroform. A scan rate of 200 nm min?1 with a response time of 1 s and a bandwidth of 5 nm were adopted. Time-dependent CD spectra at different temperatures were performed with different time intervals and recorded in 1 mm quartz cuvettes using 1,1,2,2-tertachloroethane (C2H2Cl4) or anhydrous THF as solvent. A scan rate of 200 nm min?1 with a response time of 1 s and a bandwidth of 5 nm were adopted at each temperature.  2.5 Chiral High Performance Liquid Chromatography (HPLC) Analytical chiral HPLC was conducted on a Shimadzu LC-20AD system using CHIRALPAK columns (0.46 cm I.D. ¡Á 25 cm L). Chromatographic condition for cages: IF column, eluent of CHCl3/hexane = 80/20 (v/v), flow rate of 0.6 mL min?1, UV detection at 295 nm at 30 oC. 3. Synthesis of Precursors and Cages The syntheses of all chemical compounds are described as follows. DC-1 was synthesized according to our previous literature.[S1] 2,4,6-Trihydroxybenzene-1,3,5-S5  tricarbaldehyde (TP) and 1,3,5-tris(3-bromophenyl)benzene (compound 1) were synthesized according to the literature procedure.[S2¨CS3] 1H and 13C NMR spectra of all compounds are listed after their synthetic procedures and their assignment are given in their NMR spectra in Section 10.
